sections.Position in the educational system:
The course is provided as a part of the Computer Science Master's Programme N2COS.
The course is also offered as a programme course in the Computer Science Bachelors
Programme N1COS. Please note the entrance qualifications for programme students in
NICOS below for this course. The course is also offered as a single subject course. The
course is also a Ph. D course for Ph. D students within interaction design or related
subjects. The course is also offered as a single subject course.

sections.Entry requirements:
Requirements for the course is to have successfully completed a Bachelors degree,
and have 22,5 credits from courses in Interaction Design including the course
Prototyping in Interaction Design (TIA108) 7.5credits and Interaction Design
Methodology (TIA104) 7.5credits.
To be eligible for this course as a programme student in Science Bachelors Programme
NICOS, the student must have passed at least 90 credits in programme
courses, and have 22,5 credits from courses in Interaction Design including the course
Prototyping in Interaction Design (TIA108) 7.5 credits and Interaction Design
Methodology (TIA104) 7.5 credits.
sections.Learning outcomes:
After completing the course the student is expected to be able to:
Knowledge and understanding
• describe and relate to common aesthetic ideals within interaction design,
• describe these aesthetic ideals are rooted in other disciplines,
• analyze and discuss an certain design in relation to current aesthetics ideal,
• analyze and describe interaction in itself,
• explain with the idea of the Gesamtkunstwerk.
Skills and abilities
• shape interaction in itself towards a certain expression or ideal,
• design for a certain aesthetic ideal,
• combine several aesthetic ideals in design,
• redesign interaction-related aspects of an artifact,
• motivate ones design decisions as being based on an aim of design,
• give and receive constructive feedback.
Judgement and approach
• select and apply approaches and theories from related fields in order to discuss and
attain a certain aesthetic ideal,
• choose or express a suiting aesthetic ideal (or combination of ideals) depending on
context and users,
• establish and clearly express ones own view on aesthetics of interaction.
sections.Course content:
When we say "aesthetics of interaction" we are not referring to visual appearance only.
Aesthetics of interaction is about all aspects of an artifact; not only how it looks but also
how it behaves, interacts, feels, sounds etc. Within interaction design there are a number
of different aesthetic ideals. Many claim usability as their aesthetic ideal, but there are
others too; some say that we should design for pleasure, others that we should design for
play, others yet design to criticize whereas others advocate tangible interaction, or
interaction that engages all senses. In this course we will look closer at the
abovementioned ideals and discuss and practice how to design for them. Content
includes, but is not limited to:
• Common aesthetic ideals within interaction design
• Different ways to describe interaction
• Gestalt and expressions
• Interactive artifacts as Gesamtkunstwerke
• Temporal aspects of interaction design
• Analysis of various aesthetic aspects of an interactive system or object
• The connection between design objectives, design rationale and aesthetic design
decisions
The course features both practical and theoretical parts, as well as work in groups and
individual work. Lectures, literature and literature seminars give a theoretical
foundation, which is immediately put into practice in a series of small exercises and one
larger project. Focus is upon turning analysis and reflection into practical action. Focus
is also on exchange of thoughts, feedback, designs and ideas. The course requires active
participation; apart from work with the final project, participants will spend most of
their study time at school, working in pairs or groups.
sections.Assessment:
The course is examined through three modules, namely:
1. Individual and Group-based lab exercises 2 credits (Pass/Fail)
2. Individual literature assignments 1.5 credits (Pass/Fail)
3. Individual design project 4 credits (Pass with Distinction/Pass/Fail)
sections.Grades:
The grading scale comprises: Fail, Pass, Pass with distinction.
In order to receive Pass on the entire course, the student needs to receive Pass on all
three modules. In order to receive Pass with Distinction (VG) the student must receive
Pass with Distinction at the module Individual design project 4 credits, and Pass
on the other modules.
sections.Course evaluation:
After completion of the course the students are to be given the possibility of
participating in course anonymously. Continuous evaluation will be used, including
three meetings between teacher(s) and student representatives. Additionally, the course
will be evaluated with a course questionnaire, and discussed with the student
representatives.
